reviewText:
#Edited for the first launch day#

Having played this game for 50+ hours under different conditions, difficulties and scenarious, along with getting the very first A+ score, I can safely say the following: get it. It is a 3D Faster Than Light + a few more games mixed in it (most notably Star Trek Bridge Commander) + Ironman experience.  It is there to test the fans of the rogue-like hardcore genre who do not complain about losing stuff or people, getting destroyed, then learning and adapting as a result. There is no save and load function. You roll the roulette and you live with what you've gotten in a beautiful 3d FTL-Star Trek format.

FOREWORD:
If someone says that the game has no replay value, they have played it way too little. Look at my play time. I rarely did the same run twice, unless trying to beat my previous score or testing new stuff.

The game is out of early access as of today, the 04.03.2015. Sadly, it already received a number of negative reviews during the years of development, so you will be looking at mixed reviews for a while. Most of it was because the devs were trying to find the reasons for the game not launching for a number of people, and those were readily cranking out the negative reviews. FYI, before I start with the good and the bad.

As usual, I will start with the good and the bad.

The absolute BEST:

The game generates meaningful stories through its gameplay, the type that make you take to the forums and share, be it for a win or a loss. How you had a great playthrough until everything started falling apart, people started dying, enemies were swarming you in throves and eventually destroyed you. Or how everything was so bleak, you were out of resources but managed to find a solitary planet where you safely did 6+ probe runs, restocked like crazy and won the game? Or how you went all out berserk and punched your way through the enemy lines like a boss? Or how a single rash decision on an away mission lost you two of your most valuable crew members and it all went downhill OR you still won nevertheless? Yep, all of this is possible. I absolutely love this about a game.

The Good:
1. Beautiful backdrops - the space, the planets and the suns look beautiful. The space must be black by default, but you are playing a game right?
2. The ship is also a looker. I personally love the way it appears on my screen with all of its flashing blue red and metal stuff. Once you start building structures, they will also appear inside it, which adds a new level of immersion.
3. Resource Management - picking what you want, what you need, when you need it might be the difference between defeat and a victory. Shortages really punish you, and even if you win, it affects your score big time.
4. You get to pick your ship parts - this allows for huge customization. You may pick a nimble ship with fewer systems but tons of cargo space, or you can make yourself a juggernaut. with less storage space and better weapons, absorption, shuttle missions, etc. All up to you.
5. Last ditch effort - this type of play really reels you in as you see the last 10 000 people of the human race die from lack of food, oxygen, killed by enemies and random events. Speaking about random events...
6. Random events are either detrimental (e.g. Alien Flu) or beneficial (Training for crewmembers). This forces you to deal with situations even more strategically, because while fighting, people still die.
7. Ironman - no going back. I love this type of play for certain games and this one is certainly worth it, just like FTL.
8. You have a decent grid size and you need to pick your way through it till you reach the end goal, dealing with hostile encounters, resource shortages, planet and object exploration, etc.
9. The combat - in FTL the combat was minimalistic. Shoot something and it will either hit or miss. Here, you need to think on your feet, use different coloured weapons and shield harmonics, defend and fire when necessary, evade shots, pause, think, and do your best. If you wish you can opt to play completely without pausing - that makes the combat extremely dynamic, but you will most likely suffer way more hits.
10. Strategy wins the game - trust me, I felt that. Making rash decisions isn't the best thing. You really need to accept the position you are in and adapt to it. Playing to the strengths of your ship and crew is key.
11. Renaming crewmembers - are you a Star Trek, Star Wars, Farscape or another franchise's fan? Or you like to use the names of your closest friends or family members? You can!
12. Like FTL, there are multiple ways to victory - at present, I would split them into sneaky, semi-sneaky, bold and reckless types of wins.
13. The game lets you do stuff on the fly. You just need to learn the mechanics. I am not going to spoil those for you.
14. Runs vary. A faster engine will get you to the end goal quicker, but a battle-hardened combat crew getting you trough 1 vs 3 encounters is a joy to behold.
15. Flying through gorgeous space. If you dont like it, it is simply not your jam.
16. Play-throughs take about 2 hours, which I find good for these types of games.
17. Scoring system that allows you to check how well you did in comparison to the others.
18. Many new features added since EA - 3 difficulty settings, ship setups, civilian management, more away missions, etc.
19. Replayability has been improved a lot since alpha, so you will be looking at a lot of different runs. While the end goal is the same, just like FTL, nobody forces you to reach it - a full exploration run (mine was the first full exploration run to date) takes about 8 hours.

Ok. Here's THE BAD.

The ABSOLUTE WORST:

You will ragequit if you hate games that punish you. Many a time. Get used to it, or don't buy the game.

To continue...

1. Steep learning curve - you need to play with ship setups for a while, learn how they work, what resources to pick at start, how long to stay at a planet, which awaymissions are easier and which ones harder, and so on.
2. NO multiplayer, like FTL. Can't be fixed.
3. Some bugs are still present, but the devs are all over the community forum, listening to the people and taking notes. Always good to see.
4. Combat - while I praised it, one can still find it minimalistic.
5. Punishing away missions since alpha. While the death to success ratio has been curbed a bit, and more choices given to the player, one should still exercise extreme caution when taking on away missions..
6. Some players still can't launch the game. Best check the forums before buying this game. The devs are hard at work at it.

CONCLUSION:

The game is quite the looker, and has this FTL last ditch type of feeling. Up until now, the devs have been on the money with the updates, consistently adding more content - with the last patch enabling us to manage the civilian population by adding more buildings, with the option to upgrade them in the future to avoid the constant civilian problems. Whoever says this game is short... is right, but it can also be played is a plethora of ways, adding replayability. Fastest way to goal, explore the whole quadrant, go left side, go right side, be sneaky, fight a lot, try not to fight at all. Or plain handicap yourself if U R A PRO. Just try it! I know I did, with runs with as low as 575 credits. To me, this game is one huge sandbox - I get to pick my difficulty (and by that I don't mean the pre-set ones), my setup, my way to play the game and try to win. It is fun - whether you should choose to challenge yourself or just explore the vast quardant of space and enjoy the extremely atmospheric Into the Stars.

So close to Battlestar Galactica, and yet so far. Oh devs, one day you will listen to the Tiger, damn you...
So. Into The Stars, basically, Battlestar Galactica, you are humanities last hope. A colony ship which moves at best at the speed of a flying space turtle on tranquilisers, moving across a fairly hostile chunk of galaxy in the hope of making it to a habitable planet (Titus Nova). The ship's warp core is more or less dead, you're running on limited resources, everything is going to break slowly, and you're fighting progressively worse situations as you go. It's a bit like a lot of games that involve such mechanics (think FTL and its' ilk).

Now, disclaimer, I kickstarted this game, and I wanted to get involved early because I saw the potential in this to be the big BSG experience that everyone was aiming for. It had the team behind it, it had (and has) the graphics behind it, it has the -music- damn it. What it needed was people who could be dedicated playtesters who could shape the game into something great. People with a lot of experience in the gaming arena who know what works and what doesn't. People who understand the limitations of dev time and therefore could have got the ideas in early so they wouldn't have been going down the wrong track on things like combat and so on.

Problem, the dev team was probably the least communicative that I've ever seen during the KS phase post campaign. It was definitely the least involved KS post release I've been. So I decided to stay well back and wait for the early access release, in the vague hope that hey, these guys looked professional, they'd get this right. I was partially correct.

The problem of developers who cling too tightly to their children.
Into The Stars should be seen as an exercise in why if you have a bad idea, you should discard it as quick as you can, rather than double down on it in an attempt to patch it up and make it playable. The big bugbear in this case was combat. Combat here uses a colour frequency system to determine if a shot gets past your (or your opponents shields) or not.

This is not good gameplay, because it offers no reward to the player, if they do stuff right, they're basically getting the damage from the weapon that they're supposed to get in the first place (presuming it even hits), and if they do stuff right defensively, then their shields function as advertised (yes, it's possible to hit deflect" and it do -nothing- if your frequency is the wrong colour).

reviewText:
Wow. I didn't expect this game to be this dissapointing. When you look at the screenshots and videos on the store page, the game looks like a high quality indie game, but actually it is a very very poor quality game. The only high quality thing is when you fly around in space, but even that gets old really fast.

The menus are a complete joke. Is it that hard to make good looking menus? They look extremely amateurish. And that is a big problem, because a huge of part of this game is doing things in menus. That's right. This game is almost a text adventure. But the presentation of that text is extremely boring and dull. A game which does this much much better is FTL. The presentation in that game is so much better even though that is a 2D game and there is also a lot of text based things.
The events you encounter on planets are extremel dull and boring, you don't even need to read the text really. The background pictures for the events are terrible. But the thing is also from a gameplay perspective they are all boring as hell, because there are no interesting rewards.
Getting new modules doesn't really feel like a reward, because you never get to see those modules anyway. The modules are also just texts in menus and better modules don't really have better effects. In FTL on the other you can see your entire ship. When you get a new system you can see how it is installed in a room and you can tell a crew member to man that system. Also when you upgrade the modules it gets new or better abilites. And FTL has tons of modules, it is impossible to have every module in the game in one ship. There are lots of decisions involved what module to choose and what module to upgrade. Into the stars has NOTHING of that.
The ship management is a complete joke. Well there isn't any ship management, you have city management, which is extremely weird. The proportions of the ship feel really weird. Apparently you have 10.000 people in that tiny space back in the ship, which IS tiny, if you compare it to how big the cockpit is.
The city management feels completely unneccessary and feels like they just added it to hide the fact that this game lacks any depths, so they just throw more stuff in it. But the city management itself is also extremely dull and annoying.
The game has lots of small annoying things, like how you always have to wait for that stupid animation when you switch to cockpit view, or how you sometimes have to press the button for free camera multiple times.
The mining mini game is another thing which just feels completely unneccessary.
The combat is the biggest joke of this game however. This is probably the most dull combat system I have ever seen in my life. Their poor attempt to give the combat depth with those weird frequency things is laughable. You just look at your enemy, choose a different color than his shield. That's it. You look at the enemy attack's color, choose the same color for your shields, that's it. Doesn't help that the animations are TERRIBLE, the evade animation made me laugh loudly in my room. And while the design of the player ship is really cool, the enemy ships look really bad and uncreative.

Man there is much about this game I don't like I probably even forgot half of it, and that is a big shame, because from the screenshots and videos this seemed like a really cool game, like a 3D FTL, but FTL is a billion times better. Don't compare this to FTL, just don't. All this game achieved is make me want to play FTL again.

The worst thing is I can't get a refund because I bought this from a third party website, even though this is probably the game that deserves to be refunded the most from all the games I refunded so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Into the Stars is essentially a bridge simulation, with the ever present threat of an alien race nipping at your heels to force you to keep moving. It's all about time management and hard decisions, such as working out how long you dare stay at one planet mining for essential resources without risking a fatal Threat Level Red battle encounter.

The chase across space is what makes this game feel exciting, despite the restriction of feeling confined to the captain's chair. Cutting about the galaxy at top speed, wondering if you dare veer off to explore that red planet that'll take you further from your ultimate goal (but may also stop you all starving to death), this is the good stuff.

Into the Stars gameplay video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5k5JEgh9NCU

There are other more obvious decisions the game throws at you - dialogue boxes that ask you if you want to investigate one of three points of interest on an away mission for potential reward or disaster - but it's the ongoing supply management issues that bring the game to life.

There's also a surprising 2D action mini-game to play - the further you drill into the planet, the more supplies you get to bring back to your ship.

Combat is straightforward - you can face up to 3 ships at once. One is trivial, two require careful use of shielding and three require a nerve of steel! There's no tutorial in the release I played but once you figure out that red shields protect against red weapons, yellow shields protect against yellow weapons etc, you feel a lot more in control of the encounters and feel like losing was because you made bad decisions under stress (or kept clicking the wrong damn thing!) rather than the game being unfair.

I really look forward to seeing how this game develops in early access - it's a tough game as it stands and it should stay tough, but giving the player a little more leeway for exploration of this huge world to go along with the thrill of the chase would be brilliant.

This review is of the pre-release of the early access version.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review written as of 0.01 Early Access.

The game has more than a few design issues.

-The pacing can be grueling as the ship just seems to move too slow, and watching your food and oxygen go down as you're closing on a possible encounter ship that might not even give you those resources just doesn't vibe.
- Given the fact that the setup you start the game with is the setup you will play the game with, with ship upgrades being more a matter of RNG than actual choice, and given that the initial setup is far from varied or giving any real variety to choose from, mixed with the fact that the map is static just points towards very little replayability. And since the game speed is so low.. let me touch on that.
- Game speed. Mixed with the pacing above but the game just has bad use of user interaction and timing. The 'command pause' is not always availble, including in moments where you'd want it by default on, like when interacting with planets. You're left at the mercy of shoddy animations that take too long to load up menus while you're on the clock. I have a vague feeling that using Mining Probes is a better choice than Mining Rigs in the long run specifically because the animations and time you spend  in sector is smaller, and you draw less of attention from the enemies. This is /not/ proper use of player agency within the context of game mechanics.
-Combat itself isn't horrible, but there is one single questionable design choice.. Misses. The enemy never misses, yet you do. Then again, i agree that so far what i've played your ship is quite a lot stronger, but the fact of SO many misses makes the initial weapon choice moot. Any long-charge, high-power-per-shot weapon is a ♥♥♥♥♥ier variant when compared to the higher rate of fire/charge ones just because of misses. The only choice is how much you want to micro the colors/frequency matching, but that shouldn't be a choice in itself.

Those aside, everything else can be chalked up to Early Access issues. Things like control, optimisation, animations and balance as well as placeholder names and unintuitive UI. If i want to play a great space roguelike with fantastic replayability, pacing and balance, i'll be playing FTL some more.

To note, i did Kickstart this, but i will be leaving this to stew for a good year or two until they sort it out, since for now, i wouldn't recommend it to anyone if they'd ask me for a single choice of a game to play.

Early Access Review

AN IMMERSIVE SPACE SURVIVAL EXPERIENCE


Into The Stars puts you in control of a spaceship and its crew as you lead the last vestiges of humanity from its destroyed planet in search of a new home. Faced with a series of tough survival decisions you'll constantly be on the run from the mass-murdering alien Skorn, you'll be fighting them off when you have no other option, and you'll be scrounging for every last resource you can get your hands on to survive and complete your journey.


I'll start the actual review by saying that I'm new to this genre. I've never played FTL, and quite a few of the negative reviews seem to be here because people are comparing Into The Stars to FTL. Sadly, ITS appears to be losing the intergalactic battle.

However, I have played almost 14 hours of Into The Stars in addition to the 5 or so I must have played at a friend's house on their Steam account before I rushed home to buy my own copy.
Even though I'm new to this type of game (feel free to decide for yourself how valid this review is) I can definitely recommend Into The Stars. Here's why:


PROS
- Good graphics, excellent sound effects, and wonderful ambient music that immerse you in  an outer space race for survival. Immersing the player in the game world is the most crucial aspect of a game, and Fugitive Games have definitely succeeded in this area.
- A constant pressuring feeling that you’re always fleeing from a mass-murdering, evil race of aliens due to your onboard AI alerts and the Skorn patrol ships you can see scouting the sectors of space.
- Excellent starting customisation options for your ship, your cargo, and your crew that can make a big difference to your survival success.
- A surprisingly fun mining mini-game.
- A good number of very interesting ship upgrades to be found by risking the completion of shuttle missions. Such upgrades could include a faster engine, stronger shields, or a module that increases the effiency of your life support system thus making your oxygen supplies last longer.
- Every decision you make could affect your survival. Staying on a planet a little while longer to mine for essential oxygen could allow the Skorn to find and destroy you. You have to weigh up every decision.
- Very polished for an early access title.
- Combat is simple but good fun and challenging.


CONS
- With a relatively small map, and no apparent randomisation of stars and planets, the replay value is good, but not great.
- The game does need more breadth and depth to create longer lasting appeal for players.
- Still has quite a few bugs, none that were game-breaking (at least not in my experience), but this is to be expected from early access.

On a final note, yes, the combat can be very hard and even very unfair - especially towards the start of the game. To get around this you need to train up your engineers so that their shooting becomes more accurate (I've had late game engineers who've almost never missed), and you need to avoid large fights. So in other words, flee an area as soon as you're given a yellow alert, and avoid Skorn patrol ships like the plague.


***18th December 2015 UPDATE***

-The devs have really listened to their fans and have now made it possible for the enemy ships to miss when shooting at your ship. Before, they had a 100% success rate of hitting you.
-The game now has an evade (dodge) feature that allows you to move out of the way of all incoming fire. This is especially useful if different Skorn ships are attacking you with different colour-coded weapons at the same time (your shields can block only one colour-code at a time).
-To offset these two new ways of making combat fairer on the player, Skorn ships have a new weapon. This is a very powerful charged laser attack for which you get plenty of warning. The only way to avoid taking damage from this devastating weapon is to use the game's new evade feature.


As always, leave any questions below and I'll get back to you.
Happy space ventures!

reviewText:
What's going on here?  I have a personal conflict.  I want to encourage this developer, and be positive due to what this game could be with such ridiculous ease, and I don't want to be a sucker who gives someone too much credit while they take advantage of people.

This game gives me the impression that one of six things happened.

1. A few established people tried to help a friend get started, and he didn't follow through.
2. Someone wants to test minimum development that makes a game (possibly interesting).
3. Someone wants to test the minimum fulfillment that isn't Kickstarter fraud.
4. A new, small team got started, fell out, and quit (would be sad).
5. Someone decided to milk Kickstarter and Steam for easy money without doing any work.
6. A solo dev had something really bad stop their work. (would be sad)

This game has potential that could be so easily realized that I know programmers who could finish it in an afternoon, and I could in a weekend, tops.  The interface simply isn't finished.  It has a mutually contradictory design philosophy (a short board game design that isn't short and is more RPG than board game).  It has had the same crashing and freezing bugs for six months as of this review, apparently (according to a dev post) arising from dependencies on Internet Explorer (weird and alarming).  Saving and loading are not implemented, and it deletes its own saves (player is punished for the design self-contradiction).  Its most interesting feature (away missions with stories) may be completely faked with decisions that do nothing.

It's like a game was just almost made.  Just almost.  It's like someone worked hard enough at a sham that they almost accidentally made something anyway.  Or it's like something really neat was in the works, and then something went terribly wrong.

There may be an explanation.   If at least the interface is finished, the crashes and freezes are fixed, and saving and loading is squared away, then I could write a review that forgives the potentially faked gameplay and incomplete copy of FTL's mechanics.

It's just so close to being a complete little game while falling short with such simple things that I don't know how to react to it.  Did something bad happen to the developer?  Should I feel sympathy?  Should I be encouraging a new indie dev with the guts to get started before learning to program, so maybe they'll finish their work?  Should I feel ripped off?

reviewText:
Keep in mind most of the other (negative) reviews are from early access.

Anyway, I'd give this game a buy with a caveat. If you, like me, are always searching for starship sims (less Tie Fighter more Star Trek Bridge Commander), you might enjoy this game. If you aren't, however, you probably will not like this, as it is a fairly simple, shallow experience. That experience, however, does scratch that utterly maddening starship sim itch.

This game allows you to play like you're Captain Picard or Admiral Adama, which is something a lot of us really want, but not something that's often made. Most of the games in this genre are decades old, rarely talked about or even remembered, and sometimes not even capable of being played on modern machines -- even with DosBox. This game fills that very large gap. If you are looking to sit on the bridge and take command over starship systems and crew, this is for you.

So what is the game like? It basically amounts to a series of simple mobile-like minigames superimposed over a smallish 3d open world and resource management simulator. You can pick and name your captain, crew, ship loadout (everything from weapons systems to what kind of food replicators you ship is equipped with), and starting resources. The controls are not able to be changed, but they are fine as-is and not anything that you'd worry about changing anyway. For that matter the interface is streamlined and easy to use. The mini-games are actually enjoyable, if simplistic, so the game ends up being pretty fun for the price.

The only things I dislike about the game are its lack of depth (the minigames really do feel like minigames and the away missions are just randomly generated die rolls with possible stat bonuses applied as far as I can tell) and its visual style (some may like it, but I find it a hideous mess that's aesthetically similar to the worst of bargain-bin scifi crap--lots of glowing neon, random hexes getting in the way of everything, plastic-looking textures, hideous ship design, etc). These may be deal breakers for some, but I'm willing to put up with it because A) It's cheap and B) it exists in a genre that's very rarely explored.


tl;dr It's a simpler FTL in first person, except you feel more attached to your crew and ship

Early Access Review

The only major issue I have, something that is completely incongruous with the game itself, is the menus. You can see from the screenshots yourself that the game looks incredible; maybe one of the prettiest and most evocative I have played, but the menus are amateurish and really detract from the look and feel of the game.

It’s a massive shame, but I guarantee it’ll be the first thing people notice when they boot. They won’t notice the amazing expanse in front of them, they won’t notice the ability to fly from the cockpit and amazing attention to detail that offers. It’s a shame because it’s one simple thing that will turn a lot of players off instantly.

As it stands, though, I would recommend Into The Stars to people who are willing to look past some Early Access teething pains. There’s the core of an awesome game under here, tied down by a couple of rough ideas and some dodgy execution. Look past that, and maybe have faith this stuff will get fixed, and you’re in for the game that FTL was in your mind’s eye.

Early Access Review

This is a game that is clearly in its infancy but has a strong foundation with which to work off of. No bugs, ship handles well, the controls are a little weird but you get used to them quickly, and everything works. Into the Stars is a bridge simulator and has you attempting to reach a point while dealing with dwindling supplies, aliens in pursuit, and issues that plague your ship. It's all well done and works to create a simple game that challenges you.

Boy does it challenge you. Holy crap this game is hard. It's too hard in my opinion but hey I've only played a few rounds so far and you pick up on things as you play.

This game is a little boring and frankly feels incomplete but that's why its in early access. The following are suggestions for the developers to really make this game into something great.

- reduce the difficulty or give players the option to choose different difficulties
- tips/tutorials would help a lot
- add dialogue and make the ship seem alive (have the crew move about the bridge, make them talk, have lights pop on to indicate various conditons, have more sounds, etc.) maybe people come into the bridge and confront you if you're doing a bad job captaining the ship; more dynamic events will make this game a LOT better
- add more ships into the game world; I have yet to encounter anything other than enemy ships. let's get some mining ships traveling across the galaxy, bandits who might help or hinder your progress, allied ships, etc.
- add a story to this game and some more background info. why are your civvies trying to make it to this end point?
- add way more cutscenes, cinematics, etc. I want more things to happen when I send a shuttle team to the surface of a planet (meet other races civ style, visit cities or outposts, etc.)
- add dynamic events where you have to choose an option of how to deal with the situation on the ship which has far reaching effects (ie. a crew member pioneers a new module that you must decide if you wish to utilize or the crew mutinies)
- have spaceports you can visit to interact with NPC'S, sell cargo, upgrade your ship, repair your ship, etc. these could also serve as safe zones where the enemy won't attack you

This game is still recommended as your input and experiences with it will definitely help make this game grow into something spectacular. It's 20 bucks thankfully and is worth getting into at this point.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Patch .5 Review
TLDR; Excellent visuals, great combination of a Star Trek Sim and FTL: Faster Than Light, Solid Core gameplay IDEAS but balance/execution is lacking. For $20, I’d wait. Find it on sale or wait until the content increases.

Visuals:  At the very beginning I was slightly put off by the character portraits, they seemed like stickers plopped on to the uniforms and backgrounds. The second I got into the game and took a look around I quickly changed my tune. All of the stellar objects (planets, asteroids ect…) look stunning. Solar flares in-circling the stars, the surface of the planets well detailed and each one had its own character to it. The Command Chair view also has a ton of high points, if you ignore the character models and animations. The animations for the different command functions and even the simplified city all look superb. I can forgive the repeated characters (The command deck girls all look pretty much the same) I just hope they look to improve those in the future because against the rest of the game, it seems a tad out of place.


Story: You’re the last hope of humanity running from the Scorn, your typical nomadic, devour everything in their path alien species. Pretty simple and not much explanation behind it.


Gameplay: The core of the gameplay is fairly solid. Combat is fun and the exploration side has its strong points, but the UI and its responsiveness hurts me. Sometimes it seems that what I click on doesn’t register or does slowly. Assigning crew can be a bit of a learning curve for the first few times, and all the small numbers so close to one another can send your head into a spin. One feature I’d love is while assigned to a position, the relative skill number would appear alongside the name of the skill.

The Combat itself is fun and can be intense for the first play through or two until you start to get the hang of it, and even then it has its moments of excitement as you barely bring up shields in time or duck out of the way of a laser. Audio ques are well done, mostly on point and once you learn them, have a huge part in correctly defending yourself. The issue lies in variation, it turns into the same fight over and over again. A simple strategy emerges and the skill cap is frankly quite low. You may fight against 4-5 different ships but they all are fought the same way, by the end of the third play through I was taking almost no damage verses single combatants and maybe one shot when faced against two of them, even when I finally got a 3 ship encounter, I took maybe 3 hits. My request? Toss in some variation in strategy, in enemy modules or even change up the playing field, maybe an asteroid field could provide evading ships even better defenses? Not sure about how but I know a larger variation is needed or else it becomes stale quickly.

I love the resource management, even if it seems VERY overwhelming at first, a full tutorial would go a long way. Finding the correction combination of modules that suits your resource needs is a fun way to change up how you play and can decide if you really are going to stop at the planet or just book it to the next sector. The only complaint I have is the numbers on the civilization side aren’t always very clear, the biggest one being the growth stat. I have a growth of .9%! Okay, is that .9% of my population every day? Week? Month?? None seem to be quite right. Or is it not supposed to be a %, and it’s just + .9 population every day? This last one seems to be the case, but it took until my third play through to come to that conclusion.

To round things off, I love how the game makes you work for your victories, or at least seem like it. I played three runs on normal (each run seems to last 3-4 hours with the slower, more resource efficient engine) and I felt like I earned the two victories I got. I just want a climax, both times I pretty much coasted into the finish line with nothing stopping me (Abit, the second time I was bleeding population with 0 food left :D).

ClosingOverall, a great game for someone like me who is absolutely obsessed with space exploration and sim games, the average person might want to wait a bit longer, or pick it up for a few play throughs and come back later when the game receives more content. If you enjoyed FTL: Faster Than Light and have always dreamed of being the next Kirk or Picard, this is a must pick up.

Verdict: 7/10 with tons of potential. I’ll do my best to keep up with the updates and revise as changes come along

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the game is in early access, it suffers from flaws that I believe to be fatal.

Crises come in rapid-fire sequence beyond anything remotely believable, and your crew can't fix anything without a direct order. Combat mechanics are badly flawed; shields can't defend against more than one enemy at a time, and you usually face at least two. There is only one possible way to find repair parts, and it happens so rarely that you're not likely to be able to fix any damage you take before the next fight. You can't avoid combat because resource consumption is off the charts; you have to stop at every planet and gather, gather, gather until the bad guys catch up with you or you'll die from running out of fuel.

Also note, the game is pure iron-man mode. No normal save-restore; you can shut the game down and come back the next day, but you can only pick up right back where you left off. If you die, you start over. Period.

This game is suitable only for people who hate winning and can only take a game seriously if they lose every time. Hardcore masochists only.

Tentative recommendation. What Into the Stars does well, it does very well. For other things, it is merely functional.

The good:
Into the Stars offers an interesting take on the space ship adventure game. Ark 13 is big, slow and unweildy, exactly as you'd imagine such a big ship to be. there's no point in doing clever manoevers, you basically point and let her fly. But just because it's a slow ship, doesn't mean that as the captain you'll have nothing to do. There are constant little emergencies that require your attention, for which you need to apply your specially selected crew, and by the half way point of the mission you will know there characters quite well.

The bad: Unfortunately, when you do arrive at the planets that dot your path, the gameplay becomes mediocre. Exploring planets is little more than a menu selection, and mining for resources is a rather obnoxious mini-game.

The ugly: Combat is not optimised for PC play, and leads me to think that Into the Stars is being developed primarily for the mobile market. On its own, the act of selecting weapon frequencies and sheild frequencies is a novel idea and hearkens back to the Star Trek feel. But there are no short cuts for all the buttons, meaning you have to move the mouse, making the experience clunky and un-immersive. Secondly, the enemies float right in front of your ship, looking for all the world likethose JRPG menu based combat systems.

But I still l want to play more, and you are supposed to be avoiding conflict. I hope the developers make some changes.

Into the Stars is a cool early access game! If you are a fan of surival simulation games I think you will like this quite a lot. If you are a fan of Star Trek and Battlestar Galactica I think you will love it. For an early access game it is very polished and from the 5 hours I have played I have never experienced a ctd.

presentation-
The graphics in this game are very well done utilizing the unreal 4 engine ( your ship will travel through space in real time with animated meteor fields, and ennemy encounters, etc It looks impressive. You can switch views on the fly from the exterior to the interior of the ship( this is where you will access the various menus and make your decisions.The ui and illustrations are also executed very well.

gameplay-
there is a lot of thought that went into this system. The premise is that humanity is facing extinction and must move thier last colony ship through the dangers of unexplored space to locate a new homeworld. The journey cannot be completed successfully without carefully managing your resources. There are a lot of things you have to consider, and the game does a great job of forcing you to make difficult choices. There are three difficulty settings, and I found myself struggling with normal mode because I was a noob and put all my resources into outfitting my ship with powerful weapons to fight the skorn( the skorn are an alien race trying to wipe you out as you forge a path to the new homeworld.) Because of this all my colonists died of starvation lol. So I started over on easy until I better understood how to balance my ships attributes. Certain parts you choose may be more powerful, but they will also consume more of a specific resource so you really have to be smart about how you initially set up your spacecraft when you start a new campaign. Along the way you will have to restock your resources,( i think there are 8 total attributes?) through mining minigames, and what you focus on mining in these mini games also directly relates to your overall ship composition. I think there is a great deal of customizabilty here and I'm interested in seeing what the devs have in store, regarding possible upgraded parts in the full release?

if you are a fan of these survival simulation strategy games you should definitely check this out. My only gripe is that in order to save your game you have to choose- save AND quit- there is no other option lol! You have to quit out of the game to save...
But this has been mentioned in a lot of other peoples reviews, I'm pretty sure this will be fixed in the final build. so yeah, I'm giving it a positive review. Looking forward to seeing what new content is added in the update.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of this review sounds  negative, so I'll start straight away with TL;DR... It's fun, and it's going to get more fun. Buy it.

If you've got this far, however, I'll break down the bits I didn't like so much.

Yeah... it's a poor-man's FTL with better graphics. It has combat which looks prettier, but ultimately isn't quite so engaging.

In FTL, you are basically at each decision-point in moments. In ITS you have to point your ship in the right direction and wait a while.   Frantic it is not. Atmospheric, it is.

Occasionally en-route you'll be told something is happening which needs attention, and you assign a crewmember to fix it. Essentially, this takes them out of the command pool, and you might find you wish you hadn't assigned your pilot to sanitary clean-up duty when all hell breaks loose.

Combat is basically FTL without the fun weaponry and targeting.
Your enemy charges a red, yellow or blue weapon... you make sure your shields match to limit damage.
When firing your own weapons, make sure they're a different colour to the enemy shields.
Rinse and repeat.

When you get to where you're supposed to be, the game basically whimpers to a halt and tells you how much you earned. No 'boss-fight' or challenge to face. It felt a bit flat, to be honest.

Don't get me wrong, I think FTL went too far in the other direction... but ITS had nothing.

The main way of getting resources is to mine planets. This feels a bit place-holder. You essentially move a little icon left and right to collect resources of different types. I would really love it if this was improved. Even if it's just a graphical overhaul. That way I don't sit there wondering if I've just paid NZ$17 for something out of the 1980s.

Ship customisation is basically limited to what resources your modules use. You can swap out your magnesium-guzzling engines for hydrogen engines, for example. They might go a little faster. Or not.

I like it though. On the understanding that it's Early Access and that I haven't put a great many hours into it, it's comfortably diverting.  There are a few things I'd like to see improved though:

1. Procedural universe.  At the moment, it isn't.
2. More things to do. Or at-least, more than just dragging crew into Fix It" slots.
3. A better 'end-game'.
4. More ship customisation.
5. Mining. Fix mining. Please.
6. More captains-chair engagement.  There's so much potential there for crew interaction.

I have high hopes for this one
date: and - honestly - think it's probably worth taking the punt and putting some money into it. If it gets as good as FTL... and I think the potential is well and truly there... then it's going to be a winner.\n\nIt's playable and fun now - with the caveats above - but the potential here is for an amazing piece of kit

The game has improved quite a bit since it's stint in Early Access but it is still flawed at it's core which is a shame since the devs have such a compelling idea propelling the game, it's just unfortunate that it was not executed well.

Perhaps if modding was a thing, then it's possible seeing a niche audience growing, mainly Battlestar Galactica and Bridge Commander or even Mass Effect fans.

But, as it stands, the game is just OK. I wish the devs well and hope they decide to make another Into The Stars title but with more improvements on the depth and mechanics, hell toss out some of those bog-standard rougelike tropes and make it more of a Tactical RPG with unique rogue elements. Or make something more akin to Bridge Commander 2.0, that would be a Shut up and take my money!" moment for me and many space fans.

-V"
